Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Fully Automated and Versatile Biofoundry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be to provide a fully automated and versatile biological foundry technology biotechnology to accelerate the biotechnology research and development (R&D). Biotechnology industry spends over $35 billion/year on research and development world-wide. However, the current R&D process mainly relies on manual work of highly experienced research scientists. Such manual operation is slow, expensive, and prone to human errors, which has constrained the growth of this industry. The application of such fully automated and highly versatile biofoundry may help biotech companies greatly expedite their R&D and reduce the cost. Thus, the risk of R&D can be further reduced to enable the development of more bio-based specialty chemicals, fuels, pollution remediation, as well as healthcare products for the market. Initial work suggest the biofoundry technology may have an initial opportunity in the strain development market for fermentation companies.

This I-Corps project proposes to study the specific markets for the advanced biomanufacturing technologies. The first prototype of such a robotic platform has demonstrated its throughput and versatility in the proof-of-concept studies. It is capable of conducting most molecular and cellular biology experiments with minimal human intervention. With its modular hardware and software systems, this platform can be rapidly reconfigured to a variety of tasks for engineering biological systems. The modular system architecture also allows programming of long and complex workflows that were very difficult to implement in previous lab automation systems. When used for assembling complex DNA molecules, it achieved a throughput of over 400 constructs/day with close to 100% success rate. Such throughput and consistency was unattainable by conventional manual operations. Such capacity opens the door to fast prototyping of biological systems by in silico design, such as proteins, cells, and plants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accomplishments - What was done? What was learned?

* What are the major goals of the project?

  • Evaluate the feasibility of commercializing the biofoundry technologies.
  • Discover customer segments.
  • Discover value proposition of biofoundry technologies.  

* What was accomplished under these goals (you must provide information for at least one of the 4 categories below)? 

Major Activities:

We have traveled over 20,000 miles and interviewed 100 executives, research scientists, business insiders, domain experts, as well as administrators cover a number of different industries, such as lab automation, biochemicals, animal feed, agriculture, and food and beverage industries.

Specific Objectives:

Significant results:

Key outcomes or Other achievements:

* What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided? 

  • Developing skills for customer discovery interviews
  • Interacting with professionals in a variety of industries
  • Understanding market perspectives of related technologies

* How have the results been disseminated to communities of interest?

The results of market study and customer discovery have been shared with peer entrepreneurs in the same I-Corps cohort. The I-Corps experience and customer discovery skills were shared in the University of Illinois startup community to inspire fellow researchers and entrepreneurs.

Products - What has the project produced?

  • Notes from 105 customer interviews
  • Refined business model canvas according the insights from customer interviews
  • A startup company with 10 employees and series seed investment.

Impact - What is the impact of the project? How has it contributed? 

* What is the impact on the development of the principal discipline(s) of the project?

The current research and development in biotechnology process mainly relies on manual work of highly experienced research scientists. Such manual operation is slow, expensive, and prone to human errors, which has constrained the pace of industrial innovation as well as academic research. Our team have developed a fully automated and highly versatile biological foundry, which is capable of conducting most molecular and cellular biology experiments with minimal human intervention. With the throughput, accuracy, and versatility, this system has the potential to greatly accelerate the design-build-test cycles in biotechnology R&D.

After conducting customer interviews during the national I-Corps program, the feasibility of commercialization of this technology has been validated. The results from I-Corps program helped to launch a startup company which can further improve the biofoundry platform and provide the high-throughput R&D service to the biotech industry.

* What is the impact on other disciplines?

The automated capacity of biofoundry can benefit R&D in a variety of industries such as biochemical, animal feed, food and beverages, etc. It has the potential to greatly shorten the path for new technologies in these industries to move from laboratories to commercialization.

The automated biofoundry also made it possible to “digitize” the engineering of biological systems. This allows the existing tools in electronic engineering and computer science to have new impact in biology.

* What is the impact on the development of human resources?

This I-Corp program has trained the principal investigator and student entrepreneurial lead to develop effective business models. It also prepared them for commercialization of the technology developed in the academic lab.  

* What is the impact on physical resources that form infrastructure?      

The resulted startup company as well as the biofoundry facility will become the infrastructure of the next-generation biological engineering. This commercial platform is providing R&D services to a variety of industries.

* What is the impact on institutional resources that form infrastructure?

Although the commercial biofoundry platform will be independent from the university academic research, the insights gained during the I-Corps program provided guidance for the future academic research and improvement on the biofoundry prototype in the university academic research facility.

* What is the impact on information resources that form infrastructure?

The biofoundry platform will generate new software, data, and statistical models which can in turn help improve the biofoundry as an R&D infrastructure.    

* What is the impact on technology transfer?

The customer discovery activities during the I-Corps program directly helps the development of a viable business model for commercialization of the biofoundry technologies. The technology has been successfully transferred from the university to a rapidly growing startup company to make broader impact.

* What is the impact on society beyond science and technology?

The biofoundry platform can potentially help the biotech industry develop more new functional biological systems as new therapeutics, pollution remediation, or sustainable cell factories for synthesis of chemicals products. 

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2017
Modified by: Huimin Zhao
